item.title: Understand quicksort partitioning
item.description: The most important part of understanding quicksort is to understand the partitioning function.

item.title: Stanford Machine Learning Final Week Review! Congratulations!
item.description: This week’s machine learning course is about Machine Learning Pipeline.

item.title: Stanford Machine Learning Week 10 review
item.description: This week’s machine learning course is about training large dataset and Stochastic Gradient Descent.

item.title: Stanford Machine Learning Week 9 review
item.description: This week’s machine learning course is about Anomaly Detection and Recommender Systems.

item.title: Stanford Machine Learning Week 8 review
item.description: This week’s machine learning course is about Unsupervised Learning. Supervised Learning is to learn the weights from training examples with answers. Unsupervised Learning does not have such answers in the training examples.

item.title: Stanford Machine Learning Week 7 review
item.description: This week’s machine learning course is about SVM, which is a very important machine learning algorithm.

item.title: 7 ways to boost your brain productivity
item.description: Sandra Bond Chapman met an autistic boy one day, and was fascinated by his problem solving skills. She then decided to dedicate her time and life to studying and unlocking the immense humain potential of our brain. Now she’s a leading cognitive neuroscientist at The University of Texas, discovering approaches to build brain resilience, strengthen healthy brain development and repair brain function.

item.title: Stanford Machine Learning Week 6 review
item.description: I just finished the 6th week of Stanford Machine Learning course. It’s still largely about neural network.

item.title: Stanford Machine Learning Week 5 review
item.description: I just finished the 5th week of Stanford Machine Learning course: Neural Networks: Learning. Since this week’s course is a little bit difficult. I thought I might as well write something as a reminder, so that I could look back in the future.

item.description: I have the following static factory method that creates a list view out of an int array:

item.title: Caveat! JVM cannot check a generic cast at runtime
item.description: The Java Generics is based on Erasure, which means the type check is only done at compile time, and at runtime the type information is erased.

item.title: Where are variables stored in Java, Stack or Heap?
item.description: A primitive variable “holds” directly his value itself. Examples of a primitive variable : int i, long l;

item.title: How object in Java is initialized
item.description: It’s important and fun to understand how exactly one object is initialized in Java.
